choices.A: With any MTA, the sendmail command must be run periodically by the cron daemon.
choices.C: The sendmail command prints the MTAs queue history of which mails have been sent successfully.
choices.B: All MTAs, including Postfix and Exim, provide a sendmail command.
choices.D: It is only available when the sendmail MTA is installed.

questions.question_text: What is true regarding the command sendmail?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
No, not all MTAs, including Postfix and Exim, provide a sendmail command. The "sendmail" command is typically associated with the Sendmail MTA, which is one of the oldest and most widely-used MTAs. However, other MTAs such as Postfix and Exim do not provide a "sendmail" command and have their own unique commands and configuration options.

No, not all MTAs, including Postfix and Exim, provide a sendmail command. The "sendmail" command is typically associated with the Sendmail MTA, which is one of the oldest and most widely-used MTAs. However, other MTAs such as Postfix and Exim do not provide a "sendmail" command and have their own unique commands and configuration options.
D. It is only available when the sendmail MTA is installed.

questions.question_text: Which of the following parameters are used for journalctl to limit the time frame of the output? (Choose TWO correct answers.)

comments.content: No, it's since and until. You can run man journalctl to check.

discussion.content:
The word used to restrict the records that are returned from a SELECT SQL query based on a supplied criteria for the values in the records is "WHERE". The WHERE clause is used to filter the records based on specific conditions. For example, you can use the WHERE clause to return only the records where the value of a certain column is greater than a certain number or where the values of two columns match.

In a SELECT query, the basic syntax for using the WHERE clause is as follows:
SELECT column1, column2, ...
FROM table_name
WHERE condition;
